title: 112_s1445
content: The Act is titled the "Raechel and Jacqueline Houck Safe Rental Car Act of 2011" and includes definitions. The "Raechel and Jacqueline Houck Safe Rental Car Act of 2011" defines terms such as "covered vehicle" as a motor vehicle rated at 26,000 pounds gross weight or less, rented or leased without a driver, and part of a fleet of 5 or more vehicles used for rental purposes. It also defines terms like "defect" and "person" according to specific sections of the United States Code. The term "rental company" is defined as a person engaged in renting or leasing 5 or more covered vehicles. The term "person" is defined according to section 1 of title 1, United States Code. Prohibition on rental, lease, and sale of defective cars and trucks. Prohibition on rental, lease, or sale of covered vehicles with defects related to motor vehicle safety or noncompliance with safety standards, unless the issue has been fixed before the transaction. The rental company must not rent, lease, or sell vehicles with safety defects unless the issue has been resolved beforehand. Notifications of defects received during a rental or lease period must be acted upon promptly. During a rental or lease period, if a covered vehicle is found to have a safety defect, the rental company must immediately notify the renter or lessee and offer a comparable alternative vehicle at no extra cost until the issue is fixed. This section will be effective on a specified date. The rental company must provide a comparable alternative vehicle at no extra cost to the renter if a safety defect is found in the covered vehicle, until the issue is resolved. This section will take effect 60 days after the enactment of the Act. The Federal Trade Commission will enforce the provisions outlined in the Act. Violation of section 3 of this Act will be treated as a violation of a rule under the Federal Trade Commission Act regarding unfair or deceptive acts. Penalties for violations will be in accordance with the Federal Trade Commission Act. The Act grants privileges and immunities as per the Federal Trade Commission Act. The Commission's authority is not limited by this section. SEC. 5. ENFORCEMENT BY STATES. The attorney general of a State can bring an action in a US district court for violations of the Act to obtain injunctive relief. State officers must notify the Federal Trade Commission of any civil action. The attorney general of a State must notify the Federal Trade Commission before initiating a civil action, providing a copy of the complaint. If immediate notice is not feasible, the State must notify upon instituting the action. The Federal Trade Commission can intervene in the civil action. The State must provide immediate notice to the Federal Trade Commission upon instituting a civil action. The Commission can intervene in the action, be heard on all matters, and file petitions for appeal. Nothing in this section prevents the State attorney general from exercising their powers. The State attorney general can take civil action but must notify the Federal Trade Commission. The attorney general's powers are not restricted, and no separate suit can be filed if the FTC or the United States is already pursuing the same violation. SEC. 6. CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not prevent individuals from seeking remedies under Federal or State law. SEC. 7. NATIONAL HIGHWAY TRAFFIC SAFETY ADMINISTRATION REPORT ON SALES OF MOTOR VEHICLES TO RENTAL COMPANIES WITHOUT STANDARD SAFETY FEATURES. The Administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration must submit a report to Congress within 180 days of this Act's enactment on the sales of motor vehicles to rental companies without standard safety features. The report will include descriptions of buying practices, implications on consumer safety, and recommendations for regulatory and legislative actions. The Administrator must report to Congress on the sales of motor vehicles to rental companies without standard safety features, including buying practices, safety implications, and recommendations for regulatory and legislative actions to protect consumers. SEC. 8. NHTSA report on sales of vehicles by rental companies with safety defects before recalls. The Administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration must submit a report to Congress within 180 days of the enactment of the Act on sales of covered vehicles by rental companies aware of safety defects or non-compliance with safety standards. The rental companies must report safety defects or non-compliance with safety standards on vehicles they are aware of, starting from the date of awareness until they receive a notification from the Secretary of Transportation or the manufacturer notifies owners, purchasers, and dealers of the defect. The report required by the rental companies must include a description and analysis of the frequency of sales of covered vehicles, a discussion of the effects on consumers, and recommendations from the Administrator on legislative and administrative actions to address or mitigate these effects. The Administrator must submit a follow-up report to Congress within 1 year of the initial report, detailing the sales of covered vehicles and including a description, analysis, discussion, and recommendations for legislative and administrative action. The follow-up report to Congress must include a description, analysis, discussion, and recommendations regarding the sales of covered vehicles, as well as an analysis of differences in findings between reports. It should also discuss the effects of the provisions of the Act on the sales of covered vehicles.
